questions.text: One of the nerves supplying the upper limb, the upper lateral cutaneous nerve of arm, supplying the skin overlying the posterior border of the deltoid muscle as well as covering the long head of the triceps, is a branch of:
questions.explanation:
Branch of Axillary Nerve

Supply

Anterior Branch

Supplies the anterior portion of the deltoid muscle.

Posterior Branch

Supplies teres minor muscle and the posterior portion of the deltoid muscle.

Cutaneous Branches

Supplies sensory innervation to the skin over the lower part of the deltoid muscle and the superior lateral aspect of the arm.

questions.text: Nitric oxide is derived from:
questions.explanation:
Product

Description

Nitric Oxide (NO)

A signaling molecule involved in various physiological processes

Creatine

Plays a role in energy metabolism and muscle function

Polyamines (Putrescine, Spermidine, Spermine)

Essential for cell growth, proliferation, and differentiation

Ornithine

Precursor for the synthesis of polyamines

Urea

Produced as a byproduct of the urea cycle

Proline

Non-essential amino acid with structural and regulatory functions

Glutamate

A neurotransmitter and important metabolic intermediate

Agmatine

Involved in neurotransmission and regulation of nitric oxide

questions.text: Which muscle in the larynx is essential for saving lives as it retracts the vocal cords to enable breathing?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B

Larynx Muscle

Action

Cricothyroid muscle

Lengthens and tenses the vocal cords

Posterior cricoarytenoid muscle

Abducts (opens) the vocal cords

Lateral cricoarytenoid muscle

Adducts (closes) the vocal cords

Transverse arytenoid muscle

Adducts (closes) the vocal cords

Thyroarytenoid muscle

Shortens and relaxes the vocal cords, contributing to vocalization

Vocalis muscle

Controls tension and fine adjustments of the vocal cords

Interarytenoid muscles (Oblique and Transverse)

Adducts (closes) the posterior part of the vocal cords

questions.text: Inhaling the cloth soaked in drug is:
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Huffing

Methods of substance abuse Explanation
Bagging Bagging refers to a method of inhaling substances by placing them inside a bag and then inhaling or breathing in the vapors. The bag is typically held over the nose and mouth, allowing the person to inhale the substance contained within the bag
Snorting Snorting involves the inhalation of powdered substances, typically drugs, through the nose. The substance is crushed into a fine powder and then snorted through the nostrils using a straw, rolled-up paper, or other devices.
Sniffing Sniffing refers to the act of inhaling or smelling substances, often volatile or aromatic substances.
Huffing Huffing involves the deliberate inhalation of volatile substances or inhalants directly from their container or source. The person typically places their mouth or nose directly on the container and inhales deeply, allowing the vapors or fumes to enter their respiratory system. This method is associated with the misuse of chemicals, solvents, or other volatile substances for recreational purposes.

questions.text: What is the responsibility of the doctor in recording the dying declaration of a victim affected by a fire ?

options.label: B
options.text: To record the statement even in the presence of magistrate

options.label: D
options.text: Put the person under oath before declaration

questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - T

Dying Declaration

  • It is followed in India

  • It is the statement given by the dying patient

  • This statement can be a

    • Oral statement

    • Document

  • It is based on the 32 IEA

  • The declaration can be given by

    • Victim

    • Magistrate

    • Doctor

    • Police

    • Any person

  • Not recommended

    • Oath

    • Cross-examination

    • Leading questions

Dying Deposition

  • It is followed in developed countries

  • It occurs in the presence of the

    • Magistrate

    • Defense lawyer

  • Recommendations

    • Oath

    • Cross examination is done (Best to protect the accused)

    • Leadings questions are asked

questions.text: A 37-year-old man is brought to the emergency room by his son. He complains of being unable to move his left arm and leg. According to his son, the patient was reading a book half an hour ago when he realized he couldn't lift his left arm to pick up another book. As he tried to move away from the table, he noticed that his left leg also became very weak. Additionally, he experienced double vision. The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His body temperature is 36.1°C (97°F), blood pressure is 165/100 mmHg, pulse is 85 beats/min, and he has a respiratory rate of 16 breaths/min. During the examination, it is observed that the patient has drooping of the right eyelid and his right eye is directed downwards and to the side. When requested to smile, there is a drooping of the left corner of the mouth. The strength of the left upper and lower limbs is rated as 3 out of 5, whereas the strength of the right upper and lower limbs is rated as 5 out of 5. Which region of his brain has experienced ischemia among the following options?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C -  M
